The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has held Observer status in the Arctic Council since 2019, allowing it to contribute significantly to Arctic governance through active participation in meetings, providing expertise to Working Groups, proposing projects, and offering financial contributions. Heike Deggim, Director of IMO’s Maritime Safety Division, elaborated on the organization’s focus in the Arctic and its engagement with the Council.

The pressing issues that attract IMO’s attention include ensuring the safety, security, and sustainability of shipping in the Arctic. IMO aims to mitigate risks related to search and rescue operations, pollution response, maritime safety, and environmental protection in this fragile region. The organization’s Polar Code establishes mandatory requirements for vessels operating in polar environments, enhancing safety standards beyond existing regulations. However, there is recognition that additional measures are needed, particularly for boats not covered by the Polar Code, such as fishing vessels and pleasure yachts. IMO has invited its Member States to voluntarily implement Polar Code safety measures across these vessels.

Broader maritime concerns also occupy IMO’s focus, including the enhancement of navigational charts, establishment of search and rescue facilities, improvements in satellite and radio communications, and the creation of port reception facilities for operational waste. A significant aspect of IMO’s mission is contributing to global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from shipping, aiming for at least a 50% reduction in emissions by 2050. This initiative is aligned with the Paris Agreement and supported by various practical projects aimed at fostering technology development and operational best practices, particularly in developing countries.

In the Arctic, Member States are intensifying efforts to address black carbon emissions from ships and are advocating for extending the current ban on heavy fuel oil from the Antarctic to Arctic waters. Furthermore, addressing marine litter and microplastics is a key initiative; IMO is collaborating with the United Nations Environment Program to combat sea-based sources of marine litter.

Following its accreditation, IMO has engaged with the Arctic Council through formal channels, building upon past informal collaborations on projects such as the “Guide on Oil Spill Response in Ice and Snow Conditions.” Current collaborations involve the Arctic Shipping Best Practice Information Forum, enhancing the effectiveness of the Polar Code. Upcoming meetings will continue to strengthen the communication between IMO Member States and the Arctic Council.

Furthermore, IMO is actively developing specifications for ships’ equipment in polar waters, focusing on guidelines for navigation and life-saving appliances for vessels not covered by the Polar Code. Recent sessions have led to the creation of guidelines targeting pleasure yachts and fishing vessels operating in these regions.

title: DHL and CMA CGM accelerate decarbonization of ocean freight with joint biofuel initiative
description:
DHL Global Forwarding and CMA CGM have taken a significant step toward decarbonizing global container transport.
This initiative empowers DHL customers to significantly reduce the carbon intensity of their international supply chains while accelerating the industry's transition to alternative marine fuels.
"This collaboration marks another milestone in our mission towards low-carbon supply chains," said Casper Ellerbaek, Head of Global Ocean Freight at DHL Global Forwarding.
Driving lower-carbon ocean freight solutions Through DHL's GoGreen Plus and CMA CGM's ACT+ low-carbon transport offering, shippers can integrate sustainable maritime transport into their logistics operations.
DHL's GoGreen Plus products provide decarbonized solutions across DHL's core offerings by leveraging sustainable fuels and low carbon technology.
text:
DHL Global Forwarding and CMA CGM have taken a significant step toward decarbonizing global container transport. The two companies have agreed to jointly use 8,990 metric tons of UCOME second-generation biofuel, enabling an estimated 25,000 metric tons of CO2e well-to-wake emission reduction for ocean freight transported under DHL's GoGreen Plus service. This initiative empowers DHL customers to significantly reduce the carbon intensity of their international supply chains while accelerating the industry's transition to alternative marine fuels.

"This collaboration marks another milestone in our mission towards low-carbon supply chains," said Casper Ellerbaek, Head of Global Ocean Freight at DHL Global Forwarding. "By leveraging sustainable marine fuels, we help our customers achieve their climate goals and drive real progress toward decarbonization."

Driving lower-carbon ocean freight solutions

Through DHL's GoGreen Plus and CMA CGM's ACT+ low-carbon transport offering, shippers can integrate sustainable maritime transport into their logistics operations. CMA CGM will physically bunker the biofuel across its fleet, ensuring that emission reductions correspond to DHL's Book & Claim approach. DHL's GoGreen Plus service enables customers to cut well-to-wake emissions by selecting sustainable marine fuel options for their transport, allowing reductions of up to 80% GHG emissions compared to conventional maritime fuel.

Shared ambition for Net Zero

While DHL aims to reach net-zero GHG emissions by 2050, Olivier Nivoix, Executive Vice President Shipping, CMA CGM Group, confirmed: "Our partnership with DHL demonstrates how collaboration can accelerate the shift to low-carbon shipping. ACT+ offers reliable and scalable solutions backed by our fleet designed for alternative fuels. CMA CGM, committed to Net Zero Carbon by 2050, has already cut the carbon intensity of its shipping activities by 57% since 2008 and is investing heavily in alternative fuels and dual-fuel vessels."

Both companies will continue to explore opportunities to scale up lower-carbon fuel usage and develop collaborative approaches to decarbonize international supply chains.

What is GoGreen Plus?

DHL's GoGreen Plus products provide decarbonized solutions across DHL's core offerings by leveraging sustainable fuels and low carbon technology. GoGreen Plus products are based on true value chain decarbonization. This is enabled by the 'book & claim' approach. Book & claim enables DHL to directly replace fossil fuels with sustainable fuels within the logistic company's network and allocate environmental benefits to paying customers, even when their shipments are not physically transported with the assets using these fuels. GoGreen Plus allows DHL's customers to reduce their indirect Scope 3 emissions in their value chain arising from upstream and downstream transportation and distribution. It also helps customers with voluntary reporting of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and progress against their decarbonization targets.

text:
The ANP (National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels) granted special authorization for Petrobras to market marine diesel with renewable biofuel, ensuring legal certainty, alignment with international standards, and support for the energy transition in the naval sector.

In December 2025, the board of directors of National Agency for Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels (ANP) authorized the Petrobras to market marine diesel with content of biofuel renewable, regularizing operations already underway and strengthening the decarbonization agenda for maritime transport in Brazil.

The decision has retroactive effects.This provides legal certainty to contracts signed since November and allows for the continuation of commercialization until the agency concludes the final review of the regulation governing fuels for maritime use. The ANP's approval represents a significant step towards introducing lower-carbon solutions in the maritime sector, while maintaining rigorous technical and regulatory standards.

ANP authorizes Petrobras and guarantees legal security for marine diesel.

The authorization granted by ANP allows the Petrobras continue selling what's called Verana Diesel, a marine diesel obtained through co-processing of 5% vegetable oil, characterizing the addition of renewable biofuel to the traditional formulation.

The central point of the decision lies in legal certainty. Since sales began before express authorization from the regulatory agency, Petrobras requested a special authorization with retroactive effect. After technical and regulatory analysis, the ANP (National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels) determined that the measure was necessary to regularize the existing situation and provide predictability to the market.

Furthermore, the authorization establishes clear criteria for the continued commercialization of the product until the final regulatory review is completed, avoiding regulatory uncertainty and contractual interruptions.

How Petrobras developed marine diesel with renewable biofuel.

The development of the new marine diesel It happened in a planned and transparent way. In August, the Petrobras presented to ANP The fuel production and marketing plan. In October, the first production took place at the Presidente Bernardes Refinery (RPBC), located in Cubatão, in the state of São Paulo.

Sales began in November, before formal authorization, which led to a subsequent request for regularization. This movement reflects the technical maturity of the product. and the growing demand for fuels aligned with energy transition strategies.

Diesel Verana stands out for incorporating renewable biofuel without requiring significant changes to the logistics infrastructure or the vessels' engines, a factor considered strategic for its gradual adoption in the naval sector.

Regulatory gap regarding marine diesel prompted special authorization from ANP.

The need for special authorization arose from a regulatory gap. The Resolution ANP No. 903/2022, which establishes the specifications for fuels used in waterborne transport, does not foresee the addition of biofuels to marine diesel..

Given this scenario, the revision of the standard was included in ANP Regulatory Agenda 2025-2026, under the supervision of director Pietro Mendes, with completion scheduled for 2026. Until then, the special authorization serves as a transitional instrument to allow regulated innovation.

This approach avoids paralyzing initiatives aligned with decarbonization.while preserving the agency's role as guarantor of fuel quality and safety.

ANP's technical assessment confirms the quality of co-processed marine diesel.

The technical area of ANP evaluated in detail the formulation presented by Petrobras and concluded that the product meets the quality standards required for conventional marine diesel..

The technical report also identified regulatory precedents, such as special authorizations previously granted for bunker B24, which reinforced the consistency of the decision adopted.

This point is essential for the market.because it demonstrates that the introduction of renewable biofuel It does not compromise fundamental technical requirements, such as performance, stability, and operational safety of the vessels.

Alignment of marine diesel with international IMO guidelines.

Another key factor in the decision was the alignment of the initiative with the guidelines of International Maritime Organization (IMO), which guide the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in global maritime transport.

A ANP acknowledged that the co-processed diesel from Petrobras This aligns with those guidelines by reducing the carbon intensity of the fuel without requiring immediate structural changes to the naval fleet.

This international alignment strengthens Brazil's position.This signals that the country is keeping pace with the main global decarbonization trends in one of the most challenging sectors of the energy transition.

Petrobras' strategic role in the naval energy transition.

A Petrobras has been expanding its activities in the development of fuels with a lower environmental impact, and the marine diesel on renewable biofuel It fits directly into this strategy.

Co-processing in existing refineries allows for incremental environmental gains, leveraging already installed assets and reducing technological risks. Furthermore, it creates a regulatory learning environment that contributes to the evolution of the Brazilian regulatory framework.

The initiative also sends a clear signal to the market.This shows that there is room for innovation in the fuel sector, provided it is accompanied by rigorous technical criteria and constant dialogue with the ANP (National Agency of Petroleum, Natural Gas and Biofuels).

Impacts of ANP authorization on the marine diesel market

In practice, the decision of ANP generates direct effects for the Brazilian market of marine dieselAmong the main impacts are the regularization of contracts signed by Petrobras, the continued supply of co-processed fuel and the reduction of regulatory uncertainties.

For shipowners and operatorsThe measure expands the options for lower-carbon fuels without requiring immediate changes to vessel operations. For the regulated sector, it reinforces predictability and institutional confidence.
